content: Federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs have been in existence since the National Defense Education Act of 1958. These programs offer borrowers the opportunity to have their student loan debt forgiven or repaid in exchange for service in specific fields or professions. Over 50 programs are authorized, with around 30 operational as of October 1, 2017. Loan forgiveness and repayment programs offered by the federal government forgive, cancel, or discharge a portion of an individual's student loan debt or make loan payments on their behalf. These benefits are often tied to completing a period of employment in public service or certain occupations, or as part of income-driven repayment plans. The goal is to provide financial incentives for entering public service or high-need professions, and to offer debt relief for borrowers who have not fully repaid their loans after an extended period. Loan forgiveness and repayment programs offered by the federal government provide debt relief to borrowers of federal student loans who enter public service or certain professions, or repay their loans through income-driven repayment plans. Other forms of debt relief are available for borrowers facing specific circumstances, such as disability, death, school closure, false certification, unauthorized loans, unpaid refunds, successful defense to repayment, and bankruptcy discharge. The NDSL program, established in 1958, was one of the earliest federal student loan programs to offer loan forgiveness. The NDSL program, established in 1958 in response to the Soviet Union's Sputnik launch, provided low-interest loans to college students. It also included a student loan forgiveness component aimed at increasing the number and quality of teachers in U.S. schools by canceling up to half of their student loans for full-time teaching in public schools. The NDSL program, established in 1958, provided low-interest loans to college students and included a student loan forgiveness component for teachers in public schools. The program was later incorporated into the Higher Education Act of 1965 and renamed the Federal Perkins Loan Program. Loan forgiveness benefits were expanded to include individuals serving in Head Start programs and in the Armed Forces. Other federal student loan forgiveness programs were established for professions in high-need areas, such as the Health Professions Student Loan Program in 1965. The Health Professions Student Loan Program (HPSLP) was modeled after the NDSL and offered loan forgiveness to medical practitioners in underserved areas. Currently, there are over 50 federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs authorized by federal law. Currently, there are over 50 federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs authorized by federal law. These programs aim to provide relief to borrowers through various criteria such as service types, professions, locations, and income-driven repayment plans. Each program has unique characteristics in terms of eligibility, benefits, funding, and means of providing benefits. This overview identifies parameters to broadly characterize the authorized programs, facilitating a consistent description and examination of their benefits. In federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs, borrowers must meet specific criteria to qualify for benefits. These criteria include working in certain professions or locations, or repaying according to an income-driven plan for a set period. At the end of this period, a portion of the borrower's student loan debt is forgiven or repaid. The availability of benefits may be entitlement-based or discretionary, depending on the program. Loan forgiveness benefits are available to borrowers of qualified loans, funded through mandatory appropriations. There are two categories: public service employment and income-driven repayment. Loan repayment programs offer debt relief for specific service. Loan repayment programs differ from loan forgiveness benefits as they directly repay some or all of a borrower's student loan debt or provide funding for repayment. These programs are separate from federal student loan programs and are designed to address employment needs or help agencies recruit and retain qualified employees. Availability is limited and subject to funding appropriation. The types of debt relief programs examined in this report vary in terms of federal income tax liability. Employment-focused loan forgiveness programs exclude forgiven debt from gross income, while income-driven repayment or public service employment forgiveness may include forgiven debt in gross income, leading to a tax liability for the borrower. Federal loan forgiveness and repayment programs include three categories of loans: federal student loans under Title IV of the Higher Education Act, student loans under Title VII and Title VIII of the Public Health Service Act, and private education loans. Eligible loans for forgiveness and repayment typically include federal student loans, with some programs also including private education loans. Federal student loans were previously made through the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program and the Federal Perkins Loan program, in addition to the Direct Loan program authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act. The Direct Loan program involves loans made by the government with federal capital, while the FFEL program involved loans made by nonfederal lenders with nonfederal capital. Loan origination, servicing, and collection activities were performed by federal contractors in the Direct Loan program, while nonprofit guaranty agencies administered federal loan insurance and processed loan forgiveness benefits in the FFEL program. During the period when the FFEL and Direct Loan programs both operated, loans were made through each program with similar borrower terms and conditions. Differences in availability of loan forgiveness benefits are noted. In the Perkins Loan program, institutions of higher education served as lenders and were responsible for originating, servicing, and processing loan cancelation benefits. In the Direct Loan program, Direct Subsidized Loans were available only to undergraduate students with financial need. Direct Subsidized Loans are available to undergraduate students with financial need, subsidized by the federal government. Borrowing limits apply, and in FY2017, 6.2 million Direct Subsidized Loans were made. Direct Unsubsidized Loans are available to undergraduate, graduate, and professional students without the need to demonstrate financial need. Loan proceeds can be used to cover portions of a student's cost of attendance. In FY2017, Direct Unsubsidized Loans totaling $49.8 billion were made, with borrowing limits and interest payments deferred until repayment. Direct PLUS Loans are available to parents and graduate students without explicit borrowing limits, totaling $12.5 billion for parents and $9.9 billion for graduate students in FY2017. In FY2017, Direct PLUS Loans totaling $9.9 billion were made to graduate and professional students. Direct Consolidation Loans allow borrowers to combine federal student loans into a single loan, including loans from various federal student loan programs. This feature is important for loan forgiveness and repayment programs. In FY2017, Direct Consolidation Loans totaling $48.8 billion were made, allowing borrowers to combine federal student loans into a single fixed rate loan. Perkins Loans, with a fixed interest rate of 5%, were also available to students with exceptional financial need, with the possibility of loan cancellation for those in public service.
